CatDescriptText: Cutline of related image published in Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, national edition, December 19, 1942, pg. 3, reads: "Fort Knox Amoraiders Typify 'Double V' - Interracial harmony is the keynote of war life among the Armoraiders of Fort Knox, Ky. The Fort Knox soldiers, realizing the importance of unity in all phases of their war-time program, exemplified American democracy at its best when the Army eleven invaded Pittsburgh recently for a canteen fund football engagement with the Pittsburgh Steelers.  The above picture, snapped in one of the rooms at Schenley Hotel speaks for itself.  Reading a newspaper, at the left is First Class Private John L. Foston, of Piqua, Ohio.  Seated, clockwise, around the table, Sergeant Roland Prime, of Easton, Pa., Sergeant Bill Selley, of Akron, Ohio; Sergeant Dwight Reed, of St. Paul, Minn.; Corporal Harry Steinman, of New York City; Lieutenant Carl Hoots, of Hazard, Ky.; and Lieutenant John Persky, of Abeline, Tex.  Standing behind Reed is Lieutenant Ed Pearce, of Flint, Mich.  To the left of Pearce is Lieutenant Jack Lee, of Norwich, N. Y.  Master Sergeant Ed Manse, of Orange, N. Y., is pictured at the telephone while Private David Mason, of New York City, is shown behind.  Nance.  Note the Chesterfield cigarettes, apparently their favorite brand, in sharp view atop the table.  Missing from the picture is Corporal John Moody, of Freeport, Pa., backfield star of the Fort Knox Armoraiders' football team. - Harris photo."
TitMainTitle: Members of Fort Knox Amoraiders football team, including Jack Lee, Bill Selley, Roland Prime, Dwight Reed, Ed Pearce, Harry Steinman, John L. Foston, John Persky, Carl Hoots, Ed Nance or Manse, and David Mason, gathered in room in Schenley Hotel
